title: What are the different types of exoplanets? - Quora

response.answer_text: Exoplanets are generally classified on the basis of a few characteristics like: MassOrbitComposition Classified by mass Giant planet — A massive planet; generally composed of gases or ‘ices’ like ammonia, methane, water etc.Mesoplanet — Planets that are smaller than Mercury but larger than Ceres.Mini-Neptune — Planets smaller than Uranus and Neptune.Planemo — Planetary-mass object that does not have any activity in its core.Planetar — Brown dwarfs or sub-brown dwarfs. They’re pseudo-planets.Super-Earth — Greater mass than Earth, but lesser than Uranus and Neptune.Super-Jupiter — Planets more massive than Jupiter.Sub-Earth — Planets less massive than Earth.Classified by orbit Circumbinary planet — A planet orbiting binary star systems.Double planet — Two planets orbiting each other.Eccentric Jupiter — Massive planets that have highly eccentric orbits.Extragalactic planet — Planets that are not in the Milky Way.Goldilock’s planet — A planet in the habitable zone of its star.Hot Jupiter — Massive gas giants orbiting close to its star.Hot Neptune — Less massive gas giants orbiting close to its star.Pulsar planet — Planets orbiting pulsars.Rogue planet — Interstellar planets.Classified by composition Ice planet — A planet predominantly composed of solid ammonia, methane or water (ice).Iron planet — A planet that has an iron rich core with no mantle.Lava planet — A planet whose surface is completely covered with lava.Ocean planet — A planet whose substantial fraction of its mass is made of water.Silicate Planet — A planet whose crust is made of silicate rocks.Terrestrial planet — A planet like Earth, made of rocks. Since sufficient data—like composition of core, crust, mantle, density etc.—is not available to deduce conclusions about exoplanets, they are classified broadly as: Gas giantsHot JupitersSuper EarthsRogue PlanetsPulsar PlanetsWater WorldsChthonian Planets — Gas giants that have migrated closer to its star after its formation.Exo Earths Related Info-graphic:  To know more about the detection of exoplanets, read: How do astronomers find an exoplanet? Image Source: Infographic by Karl Tate on Space.com

Five of the exoplanet types refer only to size (mass and diameter). In order, from smallest to biggest, they are rocky planets; super-Earths; mini-Neptunes; ice giants; and gas giants. Planets in the super-Earth and mini-Neptune size range may be ocean planets, having liquid-water oceans hundreds of kilometers deep.
